fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We first prove that P^+ is separated. Suppose there are two gluings of a set of descent data on a covering sieve S over A, then we have two sieves S_1, S_2 over A with compatible families s_{1, f}, s_{2, f}. Since they are gluings of the same descent data, the restriction along any morphism g : U \to A in S would be equal. Hence there is a common refinement of g^* S_1 and g^* S_2 where the two families become equal. Expanding this, there is a covering sieve on U such that g \circ h \in S_1 \cap S_2 for every h in the sieve, and s_{1, g \circ h} = s_{2, g \circ h}. But then by the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, g \circ h for all h in the said sieve and g \in S also generates a covering sieve. Hence s_1 and s_2 are already equal on a covering subsieve, and so they are equal in \Gamma (A, P^+).

Let’s see why P^+ is not necessarily a sheaf. To be a sheaf, we need to find a gluing for each compatible family. A compatible family of local sections of P^+ is a family of covering sieves S_f over U for each morphism f : U \to A in S, and for each S_f a family of sections s_{f, g} \in \Gamma (V, P) where g : V \to U lies in S_f. By the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, the union \bigcup _{f \in S} f \circ S_f is a sieve, since S_f \subseteq f^* (f \circ S_f). (Warning: f \circ S_f is not a covering sieve itself.) So we are tempted to simply construct a glued section s' by s'_{f \circ g} = s_{f, g}. Hence we need to prove s_{f, g} = s_{f', g'} if f \circ g = f' \circ g'.

Since the families s_{f} are compatible, given any g : V \to U we have s_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r} for a family of arrows r that generates a covering sieve on V. However we cannot necessarily take r = \textrm {id}, so this is not necessarily well-defined. Here is where the separatedness comes in. Notice that s_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r} forms a compatible family over V as r ranges over the covering sieve. And therefore s_{f, g} and s_{f \circ g, \textrm {id} } are both a gluing of the family. By separatedness, they must be equal. Hence our problem is solved.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Iterated plus construction produces a sheaf

Given a category \mathcal { C }, a Grothendieck coverage declares some sieves to be coverings, such that the following holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: The maximal sieve \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A) \subseteq \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A) is always a covering.
Covering sieves are upwards closed, i.e. if S \subseteq S' and S is a covering sieve, then so is S'.
If S is a covering sieve of A, and g : B \to A is a morphism, then the pullback g^* S is also a covering.
Suppose S is a sieve, then the collection of arrows g such that g^* S is a covering is a sieve itself. If this sieve is a covering, then S is also a covering.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Grothendieck coverage can be viewed as a coverage.

Given a category \mathcal { C }, a sieve S and a presheaf P : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }, a set of descent data or a compatible family is a morphism S \to P. Expanding this, it is a family of local sections s \in \Gamma (U, P) assigned for each morphism U \to A in the sieve S, such that the local sections are compatible on restriction. There is an obvious map from the sections \Gamma (A, P) to the descent data given by restriction.

More generally, given a general cover, a set of descent data is a family of sections s_i \in \Gamma (U_i, P) for each morphism f_i : U_i \to A in the cover, such that in any common restriction of U_i and U_j, the sections agree. This can be equivalently expressed as the descent data of the sieve generated by the cover.
